fr:tree.fr:mainmatter: When we study Galois theory, we will want to study the splitting field of a polynomial by studying the symmetries of its roots. But in this example, there are no symmetries to investigate because there's only a single root. This forces us to make a careful distinction between general splitting fields.

fr:title.text: Finding the roots of a polynomial over a finite field

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Finding the roots of a polynomial over a finite field

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let F=\mathbb {F}_{p}(t) be our field, which has Characteristic p but it's also an infinite field. Consider the polynomial f(x)=x^{p}-t\in F[x]. Let \Bbbk / F be a splitting field for f(x), and let \alpha \in \Bbbk be a root of f(x). Then we have f(x)=x^{p}-\alpha ^{p}=(x-\alpha )^{p}. Then all the roots of f(x) in \Bbbk are equal.

Let m_{\alpha }(x) be the minimal polynomial of f(x) over F. Then it must equal m_{\alpha }(x)=(x-\alpha )^{k}. If p=kq+r (where 0\leq r<p), then f(x)=\bigl (m_{\alpha }(x)\bigr )^{q}\cdot (x-\alpha )^{r}, so that (x-\alpha )^{r}\in F[x]. Since (x-\alpha )^{k} is the minimal polynomial, and r < k, it follows that r=0.
It follows that x^{p}-t is irreducible over \mathbb {F}_{p}(t), yet all its roots in the splitting field are equal.
